results.title: CATARACT (concrete)
results.credit_line:
Daniel von Sturmer. Aotearoa New Zealand

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop

Commissioned by ACMI
results.material_description: Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video
results.brief_description: Everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality.

constellations_primary.name: Now watch this
constellations_primary.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

results.headline_credit_for_label:
Australia, 2020

Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video. Indefinite loop.
results.description:
Exploding fireworks, bubbles in the atmosphere, an untouched swimming pool.

Small everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage of images reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality. But with so much happening, how do we focus on a singular experience and create meaning?

That is the central question von Sturmer raises in this multi-screen work, which uses impromptu recordings and tabletop experiments to invite the viewer to negotiate between singular moments and discordant fragments of experience.
description_for_label:
Exploding fireworks, bubbles in the atmosphere, an untouched swimming pool.

Small everyday moments of existence are presented across 60 screens as a complex cacophony of events in CATARACT (concrete). This dynamic and overwhelming assemblage of images reflects the abundance of moments and messages we encounter in the world, which is represented as a complex and synthesised totality. But with so much happening, how do we focus on a singular experience and create meaning?

That is the central question von Sturmer raises in this multi-screen work, which uses impromptu recordings and tabletop experiments to invite the viewer to negotiate between singular moments and discordant fragments of experience.

display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Foyer → Entry → FSF-04. Daniel Von Sturmer

display_values: Aluminium structure, LCD screens, HD video

results.title: Cigarettes
results.material_description:
Digital video, bespoke artist box
edition 4 of 6 (+2 artist's proofs)
single channel 4:3 animation, colour, silent, continuous loop
media player, two SD cards, archival USB drive
results.brief_description:
“Cigarettes” is a single-channel projected animation, created as part of the “Christian Marclay: Six Animations” exhibition, which debuted at 49 Geary Street, San Francisco, April 28 – June 25 2016. In this animation, static photographs of cigarette butts have been edited together and played back in quick succession to give the illusion of motion.

Unlike traditional animation in which the setting is consistent and spatial continuity is maintained, in this work the background changes frantically. The flickering images recall flip-books, early cinema, and animation devices of the late nineteenth century, such as the zoetrope used by Eadweard Muybridge. Marclay’s animations set the discarded trails of rubbish in motion, giving the humble objects new life and transforming his chance encounters with trash into visual poetry.

Sourced from Fraenkel Gallery: https://fraenkelgallery.com/exhibitions/christian-marclay-six-new-animations

results.title: The Blinds and the Shutters
results.brief_description: This works presents a virtual world comprised of a modernist fictional house in a remote forest setting, whose contents gradually spill and float out of every aperture. Shoes and dresses, pots and pans, cutlery, pillows, blankets and plates journey in two directions simultaneously, some disappearing into the distance never to return, others appearing across all four screens in the installation. The larger objects fade up like apparitions, disappear and then reappear in strange locations, breaking all logic that is guiding this imaginary world. The slow drift of these household objects around the four screens is uncanny. While their journey suggests that the natural phenomenon of air is present, there is also a sense of airlessness; a claustrophobic, almost heavily scented environment. Despite sharing an energy force within the virtual environment, these objects are estranged – for they have lost their domestic relationship with one another. The sounds of bumps, collisions and muffled shuffles emerging from the interior of the house underscores the mystery of this scene. The disturbing atmosphere is most bizarre when the household goods are propelled into outer space, taking on the form of miniature satellites presumably tracking our behaviour from afar.

results.title: Play It Again II: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again II project aims to document, preserve, and create an accessible and playable history of Australasian videogames and videogame culture from the 1990’s.

This collection comprises physical games and hardware donated to ACMI for the project and as well as game emulation files created by ACMI or harvested from external web repositories.

The project is being undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Flinders University, University of Melbourne, The New Zealand Film Archive, Berlin Computerspiele Museum, and the Research Trust of Victoria University of Wellington. Funding comes from the Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Projects scheme, which funds collaborative projects between University researchers and Partner Organisations. Play It Again II is a continuation of Play It Again I, which focused on preserving Australasian videogames from the 1980’s.

results.title: Shadowrun [SNES]
results.creator_credit: Data East USA and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cartidge videogame. Cartridge, reference sheet and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
The world of Shadowrun is defined by the Awakening, where magic has been re-discovered, and human beings have accepted the existence of those they thought to be fantasy creatures. Mega-corporations and cyberworlds now share the world with elves and Native American shamans.

The player is Jake Armitage, a seemingly ordinary data courier who is assassinated by a hit squad in the year 2050 in Seattle, Washington. A mysterious figure rushes to Jake and cast a spell on him and he wakes up in the morgue with complete memory loss. Jake must now begin to unravel the mystery of his death and miraculous resurrection.

The game is a skill-based role playing game (RPG) with action-oriented combat. The player can use firearms and learn magic spells, primarily with defensive and support capabilities. The game was a critical success, winning a number of industry awards, but was a commercial failure nevertheless. It was retrospectively acclaimed by several publications as an “ahead of its time” milestone in the history of the role-playing genre for the consoles and credited for having pioneered film noir style in video games.

results.title: Powerslide [PC]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description: After an environmental holocaust killed 98% of the world’s population, the survivors above ground turned to modifying and racing the cars left over in the ruins of civilization. In the ruined world of Powerslide, players race through abandoned cities buried in sand, ruins of a dam, abandoned mine shafts, and other desolate landscapes. Perform death-defying jumps and slide through the corners as you eke out each win! This racing sim has full car dynamics, force feedback, and full multiplayer support.

results.title: Gumboots Australia [PC]
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. One 3 1/2 inch floppy disk and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Explore Australia and help solve a plethora of mysteries in Gumboots Australia. In this this adventure and educational game, the player is tasked with solving cases as an investigator for the Gumboots Enquiry Agency, a job that will take the player all over the country. The player will get to visit locations as varied as Kakadu to Coober Pedy in their hunt for the next clue. Getting there is its own challenge, as different modes of transportation can cost time and money. Random events along the way aid or hinder the player’s quest to solve the case.

results.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen [DOS]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, registration card and installation guide in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Flight of the Amazon Queen is a point and click adventure where you play Joe King as he uses his plane, the Amazon Queen, to fly famous actress Faye Russell to a film shoot. When the plane crash lands in a remote jungle, and he must use his wits to battle his way out of the dangers he faces.

As with many point and click adventures, a set of icons at the bottom of the screen allows the player to interact with other characters or the environment. The game has since been ported to smartphones, with the addition of improved graphics, full voice acting, multi-language support and a play through of the interactive interview mini-game with audio commentary by John Passfield, one of the game’s designers.

results.title: The Dame Was Loaded [DOS]
results.creator_credit: Philips Interactive Media, Inc. and Beam Software
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. Two CD-ROM, CD case insert and manual in 2 CD capacity jewel case
results.brief_description: The Dame Was Loaded is a detective mystery adventure game reminiscent of private eye movies of the 1940’s. The player controls detective Scott Anger, who is hired by a mysterious woman to find her missing brother, Dan. What at first appears to be just another missing persons case, opens up a much larger web involving Dan’s dark past. The game requires the player to use sleuthing skills to interact with characters, represented by live actors, and solve puzzles.

results.title: Play It Again I: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again I project aimed to create a playable history of Australasian video games for industry, community and research purposes, by building on existing research into the history of Beam Software and their games from the 1980s.

This collection comprises physical games donated to ACMI for the project, audio captures and game emulation files - some created at ACMI as part of the project research and some harvested from external web repositories.

The multi-faceted project brought multidisciplinary expertise to bear on the areas of collections, preservation, accessibility, fan knowledge, and the telling of histories about Australia’s digital game history.

The project was undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Flinders University, University of Melbourne, The New Zealand Film Archive, Berlin Computerspiele Museum, and the Research Trust of Victoria University of Wellington. It was funded via the Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Projects scheme, which funds collaborative projects between University researchers and Partner Organisations.

The project was completed in 2015.
